Since April 2020, the leader of the Labour Party is [Keir Starmer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keir_Starmer).

The House of Commons [states](https://researchbriefings.files.parliament.uk/documents/SN03938/SN03938.pdf) that a leadership election is held if there is a vacancy in that role (such as from a resignation or vote of no confidence), or if the Leader is challenged prior to the annual session of the Party conference.  The incumbent is not required to be nominated and is automatically on the ballot; other candidates must recieve nominations from at least 10% of elected [MP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_of_Parliament_(United_Kingdom))s (or at least 20% if the Leader is being challenged).  Candidates are elected by party members with an [instant-runoff system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instant-runoff_voting).

In June 2022, [The Times](https://archive.ph/t5GyY) reported that Keir Starmer was preparing his colleagues for a new leadership election if he was called to step down (for instance, in response to the ["beergate" scanadal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keir_Starmer#Partygate_and_Beergate_controversy)).  The Times named [Wes Streeting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wes_Streeting) and [Lisa Nandy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lisa_Nandy) as likely candidates.

While declining Labour poll ratings (especially after 2024), party infighting, and events such as a potential catastrophic result in the May 2026 local elections do slightly raise the probability of a leadership contest, experts concur that the procedural and cultural base rates make Burnham's path extremely narrow. All experts note that no Labour leader in modern times has come from outside Parliament, and party elites have strong incentives to keep outsider or disruptive figures from competing. The only plausible scenario for a 'Yes' outcome involves a simultaneous crisis forcing Starmer out, a sudden safe-seat vacancy, a rapid realignment of NEC power (perhaps driven by Lucy Powell's possible deputy leadership win), and Burnham overcoming all structural hurdles—an exceedingly rare confluence. By contrast, the default (and strongly favored) scenario is that any leadership contest is won by a sitting MP, likely a frontbencher. Burnham's appeal to grassroots members and popularity in polling are recognized as real but moot if he cannot reach the ballot. In summary, across all expert perspectives, the base rate and institutional barriers dominate, resulting in a consensus that Burnham is an outsider with a very low, albeit nonzero, probability of winning the next Labour leadership contest.
